Class Location

java.lang.Object
  Location

public class Location
extends java.lang.Object

A Location encodes a row and column on a Chess board. This is preferable to storing these values separately, because it performs error checking; if a Location object exists, then it corresponds to a specific spot on the board. This is not true of an arbitrary int and char. Locations are stored using Chess' algebraic notation, consisting of an int (1-8) for the row, and a char (a-h) for the columns. Additionally, there are some helpful static methods in here for returning all Locations a piece must go through to move diagonally, for example, from one Location to another. These are useful for Step 4.

Constructor Summary
Location(char col, int row)
          This constructor takes a char and an int, and creates a Location object out of it.
Location(int colIndex, int rowIndex)
          This construct builds a Location from two array indices; in other words, given two ints 0-7, it builds a Location with the matching char (a-h) and int (1-8).
Location(java.lang.String s)
          This constructor takes a String consisting of a char, followed by an int, like "a5".
 
Method Summary
static Location[] colLocations(Location start, Location end)
          Given two Locations, on a column, returns an array of Locations between the two, NOT including start, and INCLUDING end.

          Given two Locations, on a diagonal, returns an array of Locations between the two, NOT including start, and INCLUDING end.

Constructor Detail

Location

public Location(java.lang.String s)
         throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
This constructor takes a String consisting of a char, followed by an int, like "a5".

Parameters:
s - A 2-character String like "a5" encoding a location on the board.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the String cannot be parsed into a valid Location, or if the int and char do not correspond to a spot on the chess board, then it will throw an IllegalArgumentException; the Exception's message contains which one is the problem.

Location

public Location(char col,
                int row)
         throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
This constructor takes a char and an int, and creates a Location object out of it.

Parameters:
col - A char containing the column of the Location.
row - An int containing the row of the Location.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the parameters do not correspond to a spot on the chess board, then it will throw an IllegalArgumentException.

Location

public Location(int colIndex,
                int rowIndex)
         throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
This construct builds a Location from two array indices; in other words, given two ints 0-7, it builds a Location with the matching char (a-h) and int (1-8).

Parameters:
colIndex - The index of the column: (0-7, inclusive)
rowIndex - The index of the row: (0-7, inclusive)
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the indices are out of legal bounds
Method Detail

getRow

public int getRow()
Returns the row of the Location. This will be an int between 1-8, inclusive.

getCol

public char getCol()
Returns the col of the Location. This will be a char between a-h, inclusive.

getRowIndex

public int getRowIndex()
Returns the "computer science" equivalent of the row; in other words, instead of 1-8, it returns 0-7. This is helpful for putting Locations into arrays.

getColIndex

public int getColIndex()
Returns the "computer science" equivalent of the col; in other words, instead of a-h, it returns 0-7. This is helpful for putting Locations into arrays.

toString

public java.lang.String toString()
Returns, for example, the String "a5"

Overrides:
toString in class java.lang.Object

equals

public boolean equals(java.lang.Object o)
Determines if two Locations are equal.

Overrides:
equals in class java.lang.Object

diagLocations

public static Location[] diagLocations(Location start,
                                       Location end)
Given two Locations, on a diagonal, returns an array of Locations between the two, NOT including start, and INCLUDING end.

Parameters:
start - The Location where the chess piece is beginning.
end - The Location where the chess piece is ending.
Returns:
The array of Locations between start and end, including end, and not including start.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if start and end are not on a diagonal.

colLocations

public static Location[] colLocations(Location start,
                                      Location end)
Given two Locations, on a column, returns an array of Locations between the two, NOT including start, and INCLUDING end.

Parameters:
start - The Location where the chess piece is beginning.
end - The Location where the chess piece is ending.
Returns:
The array of Locations between start and end, including end, and not including start.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if start and end are not on a column.

rowLocations

public static Location[] rowLocations(Location start,
                                      Location end)
Given two Locations, on a row, returns an array of Locations between the two, NOT including start, and INCLUDING end.

Parameters:
start - The Location where the chess piece is beginning.
end - The Location where the chess piece is ending.
Returns:
The array of Locations between start and end, including end, and not including start.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if start and end are not on a row.
